articles.author: Anne Kauranen, Sabine Siebold
articles.description: The 12-day 'Freezing Winds' drill was part of a push to step up the transatlantic defence alliance's protection of infrastructure in waters that carry 15% of global shipping traffic and are seen as increasingly vulnerable to attack.
articles.title: As sabotage allegations swirl, NATO struggles to secure the Baltic Sea

articles.author: Maha Dahan, Yousef Saba
articles.description: The sophisticated smuggling network that some experts believe generates at least $1 billion a year for Iran and its proxies has flourished in Iraq since Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani took office in 2022.
articles.title: Fuel oil smuggling network rakes in $1 billion for Iran and its proxies

articles.author: Tom Balmforth
articles.description: The 1994 Budapest Memorandum saw Kyiv give up the world's third largest nuclear arsenal.
articles.title: Ukraine pushes for NATO invite 30 years after failed nuclear deal

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: Israeli military strikes killed at least 12 Palestinians across the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, most of them in the town of Beit Lahiya on the northern edge, medics said, as the army issued new evacuation orders in the south of the tiny enclave.
articles.title: Israel issues new evacuation orders in Gaza, kills 12 people

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: France is at a turning point due to uncertainty over the country's budget and the future of the government, Finance Minister Antoine Armand said on Tuesday.
articles.title: France at turning point amid budget uncertainty, finance minister says

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: A Turkish court has jailed pending trial nine protesters who disrupted President Tayyip Erdogan's speech in Istanbul last week, accusing his government of continuing oil exports to Israel despite a publicised embargo.
articles.title: Turkish court jails protesters over Erdogan speech disruption

articles.author: Suleiman Al-Khalidi, Maya Gebeily
articles.description: Hundreds of fighters from Iran-backed Iraqi militias crossed into Syria overnight to help the government fight rebels who seized Aleppo last week, Syrian and Iraqi sources said on Monday, and Tehran pledged to aid the Damascus government.
articles.title: Iraqi militias enter Syria to reinforce government forces, military sources say

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: An overnight Russia drone attack has left Ukraine's western city of Ternopil without electricity, a regional military official said on Tuesday, a week after Moscow's strikes cut power to much of the city and its surrounding region.
articles.title: Russian drone attack leaves parts of Ukraine's Ternopil without power, military says

articles.author: Joyce Zhou
articles.description: Five weeks ago, Moshe Weinstein found the body of his son Omer and four farm workers killed by a Hezbollah rocket, their bodies lying in an apple orchard that he has cultivated for years.
articles.title: Israeli farmer whose son was killed by Lebanon rocket works to restore orchard

articles.author: Mandy Leong, Hasnoor Hussain
articles.description: Residents in the Malaysian town of Tumpat were returning to submerged homes and shops as deadly floodwaters eased in some areas following the worst floods in decades over the weekend, and more heavy rain was forecast as soon as Tuesday.
articles.title: Malaysians return to devastated homes as floodwaters recede; more rain expected
